alert.note: Alert for Mono (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued June 19 at 8:43AM PDT until June 22 at 11:00AM PDT by NWS Reno
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Reno NV has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in California... West Walker River Near Little Walker and Coleville affecting Mono County. .Recent warm temperatures and strong mountain winds have accelerated snowmelt, resulting in a rise in the streams feeding the West Walker River. Another day of gusty winds will maintain an accelerated snowmelt despite cooling temperatures. As winds decrease Tuesday and Wednesday, snowmelt should slow and allow river levels to fall. For the West Walker Above Topaz Lake...including Little Walker and Coleville...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS MORNING TO LATE THURSDAY MORNING... ...REPLACES RIVER FLOOD ADVISORY... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...West Walker River Near Little Walker and Coleville. * WHEN...From this morning to late Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 6.0 feet, Flood stage. Minor flooding of lowlands pasture & rural roads in West Walker River Canyon and Antelope Valley including Walker, Coleville and Topaz California. At 6.5 feet, Moderate flooding of lowlands, pastures and some rural roads from the West Walker River Canyon to Topaz Lake .including Walker Coleville and Topaz California. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 AM PDT Monday the stage was 6.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:30 AM PDT Monday was 6.6 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate between minor and moderate flooding through Tuesday night with a maximum value of 6.6 feet tonight. The river is forecast to gradually fall below flood stage Thursday morning. - Flood stage is 6.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.cnrfc.noaa.gov. The next statement will be issued Tuesday.
